message.content: A Hendiadys is a figure of speech in which two grammatically parallel ideas are joined by "and" but each idea contains an opposite or contradictory element. This creates a paradoxical effect that emphasizes the complexity and richness of meaning. For example, "He was both happy and sad." In this case, "happy" and "sad" seem to be incompatible, yet they are joined together by "and," creating a complex emotional state for the subject.
